Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.

content:
Exploring relationships between countries’ environmental variables On a global scale, countries vary in many environmental factors, such as temperature, precipitation, and elevation. To explore correlations between nine different environmental variables, I performed a Principal Component Analysis on a dataset of environmental values by country compiled from the Google Earth Engine by Zander Venter. These data are non-normalized summary statistics calculated from remote sensing data.
Wrangling and data exploration # Install necessary packages. library(tidyverse) library(janitor) library(naniar) library(VIM) library(skimr) library(ggfortify) library(here) # Read in the data env_data <- read_csv(here("data", "world_env_vars.csv")) # Explore the data set for missingness gg_miss_var(env_data) matrixplot(env_data) skim(env_data) #Maybe wind isn't a great variable to use...55 missings. The others have just a few missing values. Tree canopy cover has 11, but I'll keep it. To run PCA, you can't have any NA's, and I'd rather not have a wind variable than remove 11 full countries' data. # So, I'll drop the wind column, and then the remaining NA's env_subset <- env_data %>% select(-wind, -Country) %>% drop_na() # I'm going to pare the data down to first reduce redundancy (like mean rainfall, max quarterly rainfall) and to select just a few environmental varaibles that I think might be correlated. # I've chosen elevation, aspect, slope, cropland cover, tree cover, isothermality (how variable a country's yearly temperature fluxuations are), annual rainfall, annual temperature, and number of cloudy days. env_subset_2 <- env_subset %>% select(elevation, aspect, slope, cropland_cover, tree_canopy_cover, isothermality, rain_mean_annual, temp_mean_annual, cloudiness) %>% rename("cropland cover" = cropland_cover, "tree canopy cover" = tree_canopy_cover, "annual mean rainfall" = rain_mean_annual, "annual mean temperature" = temp_mean_annual)  Running a Principal Component Analysis for a select few variables: # And I can now run a PCA env_pca_2 <- prcomp(env_subset_2, scale = TRUE) env_pca_2 screeplot(env_pca_2) # And visualize it... biplot_2 <- autoplot(env_pca_2, colour = NA, loadings.label = TRUE, loadings.label.size = 3, loadings.label.colour = "black", loadings.label.repel = TRUE) + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-0.2, 0.2)) + scale_x_continuous(limits = c(-0.15,0.1)) + theme_bw() + labs(title = "Principal Component Analysis of Environmental Variables") biplot_2 ggsave("env_biplot.png", plot = biplot_2) Fig. 1 Principal component analysis comparing country’s mean elevation, mean slope, percent cropland cover, percent tree cover,yearly temperature variability (isothermality), mean annual rainfall, mean annual temperature, and average cloudy days per year. Principal components 1 and 2 explain 58% of variance in the data
 A principal component analysis reveals a few revealing correlations:
 annual mean temperature is strongly negatively correlated with elevation the percentage of a country covered by cropland is negatively correlated with isothermality cloudiness, tree canopy cover, and mean rainfall are positively correlated elevation and cropland cover are somewhat positively correlated  Though interesting, these data are somewhat problematic: country size varies greatly on a global scale, and environmental conditions vary widely within larger countries. Binning countries by size or breaking down larger countries into smaller regions may better elucidate correlations between other variables.

When we ski, we scare away alpine animals. That’s putting them at risk, scientists say.
Gabriel De La Rosa
This past New Year’s Day, I found myself shimmying my way uphill on touring skis, trying to keep up with a spry, acclimated group of friends. We were about an hour away from Boulder, Colorado, my newfound home. I had moved here to ski, to live near the towering alpine cirques and rolling slopes of the Rocky Mountains. And here I was, a few days in, fighting the effects of altitude for a bit of wintertime adrenaline.
Not once during our New Year’s ski did I consider how our group of skiers might be disrupting alpine species. Like many of my skiing friends, I assumed backcountry recreation was an ecologically benign activity. We practice “leave no trace” principles, travel in mostly small groups, and stick to established trails. We try to leave the places we visit just as we found them.
But, despite our best efforts to limit our impact, wintertime recreation does disturb alpine fauna. New research is finding that skiing and snowmobiling are much more disruptive to certain species than previously assumed. A new study, for example, finds Canada Lynx respond negatively to increasing numbers of skiers and snowmobilers in Southern Colorado.
To understand how backcountry travel affects lynx, researchers at the Rocky Mountain Research Station outfitted recreational snowmobilers and skiers with small GPS devices through winter. They tracked lynx using GPS collars, and mapped GPS data to look for overlap, or lack thereof, of lynx and winter recreationalists. Researchers found that recreational backcountry travel, particularly snowmobiling, causes lynx to migrate out of otherwise suitable habitat. Habitat reduction can cause species numbers to decline.
A new risk to lynx is particularly important: their Colorado population has only recently stabilized. In 1970, Lynx were pushed to local extinction in the Rocky Mountains by overtrapping and property development in alpine areas. Amazingly, an ambitious 1999 reintroduction effort resurrected the lynx population in Southern Colorado. But, snow sports are putting this “saved” species at risk once again. Snowsports harm animals other than the lynx, too. Many bird populations are fragmented by skiing; their habitat is significantly reduced when mountains are turned into ski resorts. Male pine martens, a small rodent, see higher mortality near ski resorts than in the wild. Mammals, especially moose, expend unnecessary energy to avoid humans in the wilderness. Surprisingly, human powered recreation, like backcountry skiing, is more disturbing to fauna than backcountry motorsports like snowmobiling.
The findings that lynx and other animals react negatively to snow sports illustrates an important point: as human populations grow in mountain regions, and more people venture farther and farther into pristine backcountry environments, we must understand and mitigate our effects on once undisturbed species.
Knowing how wildlife responds to both urban and backcountry disturbance can help inform where public land managers decide to put infrastructure. In the backcountry, roads, trailheads, and snowmobile parks concentrate recreation to specific areas. Closer to town, ski resorts clear swaths of forest to accommodate groomed runs. New housing expands uphill and into once wild forest. New roads segment existing groves; old roads see more and more car traffic. Picking strategic locations for development can concentrate recreation to well defined areas and limit the spread of human impact on alpine environments.
We can keep skiing, and keep the lynx alive. But, we must be conscious of our impact on alpine wildlife. We must obey off limits areas and support managed access plans in wilderness areas. We can do this by listening to the research, and implementing science based management in wilderness areas. And, we must continue to leave no trace, to stick to established trails, and

Exploring Snowshoe Hare population in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest Snowshoe Hares are a keystone prey species in boreal forests. Snowshoe hare population density influences the ecosystem in both bottom-up and top-down ways: hare population density is linked to both vegetation abundance and predator abundance (Stenseth et al, 1997). Here, snowshoe hare weights and population density are compared through time.
Data were obtained from the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest Long Term Ecological Research Program.
Baby snowshoe hare. NPS Photo
 Results # Read in necessary packages library(tidyverse) library(janitor) library(lubridate) library(gridExtra) library(ggridges) library(naniar) library(ggpubr) library(viridis) library(kableExtra) library(here) # Read in the data snowshoe <- read_csv(here("data", "showshoe_lter.csv")) %>% select(-time) # Make dates dates, and clean up some entries snowshoe_date <- snowshoe %>% mutate(date = mdy(date)) %>% mutate(month = month(date)) %>% mutate(year = year(date)) %>% mutate(grid = tolower(grid)) %>% mutate(age = tolower(age)) %>% mutate(sex = tolower(sex)) # Let's explore snowshoe hare weights over time # Select for just weight and dates weight_yr <- snowshoe_date %>% select(date, weight, year) # And, I'll just explore this with a quick histogram ggplot(data = weight_yr, aes(x = weight)) + geom_histogram() # And then break weight distribution down by year using a ridgeline plot weight_plot <- ggplot(data = weight_yr, aes(x = weight, y = fct_rev(as.factor(year)), fill = stat(x)) ) + geom_density_ridges_gradient(scale = 3, rel_min_height = 0.01) + theme_bw() + labs(y = "", x = "Weight (g)") + theme(legend.position = "null", axis.text.x = element_text(hjust = 0.8)) + scale_fill_viridis() + scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0, 2500), expand = c(0,0)) # This would be cool with a total population size plot next to it # Let's count the observations per year year_count <- weight_yr %>% group_by(year) %>% count() # Then plot year_plot <- ggplot(data = year_count, aes(x = year, y = n)) + geom_line() + coord_flip() + theme_bw() + scale_x_reverse(limits = c(2012.6, 1995), expand = c(0,0), breaks = seq(from = 2101, to = 1998, by = -1))+ scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(0, 250, 500), limits = c(0, 500), expand = c(0,0)) + labs(x = "", y = "Count") + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(hjust = 0.8)) # Put the plots next to each other using ggarrange() wt_count <- ggarrange(weight_plot, year_plot, ncol = 2, widths = c(3,1)) # Then add a title using fig_annotate fig_annotate <- annotate_figure(wt_count, top = text_grob("Snowshoe hare weights and counts, 1998-2012", size = 14, face = "bold")) fig_annotate ggsave("wt_fig.png", plot = fig_annotate) Fig. 1 Density plot showing snowshoe hare weight distrubutions per year, from 1998 to 2012 (left plot). Second plot shows total counted hares per year (right plot).
 Weight distrubution for adult snowshoe hares remained relatively stable between 1998 and 2012 (Fig 1). High density of low-weight hares, likely indicating a juvenile-skewed demogaphic, often preceeded population rebounds (eg. in 2002 and 2003). However, a low-weight population in 1999 actually preceeded a significant population decline. Cyclic hare growth is characteristic of the predator-prey interaction model, where periods of high prey growth are followed by significant predator population increases, which then cause prey population decline.
# Let's make a table of mean weights per year, with standard deviations and hare counts per year # First, select and summarize our data so it will look nice in a table hare_table <- weight_yr %>% select(-date) %>% group_by(year) %>% summarize(mean = round(mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE), 2), stdev = round(sd(weight, na.rm = TRUE), 2), n = n()) # And then make a table using kableExtra hare_table <- kable(hare_table, col.names = c("Year", "Mean (g)", "Standard Deviation", "Number of Observations"))%>% kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped"), full_width = F) %>% add_header_above(header = c("Average Yearly Hare Weights" = 4)) %>% scroll_box(width = "100%", height = "200px")   Average Yearly Hare Weights     Year  Mean (g)  Standard Deviation  Number of Observations      1998  1704.75  179.61  60    1999  1250.38  392.53  392    2000  1376.64  401.62  260    2001  1390.21  405.16  102    2002  1201.57  417.69  38    2003  1212.72  310.42  59    2004  1472.16  376.84  97    2005  1269.00  407.61  174    2006  1364.58  302.85  193    2007  1371.70  346.12  203    2008  1317.25  395.38  351    2009  1337.73  272.28  491    2010  1392.84  251.94  402    2011  1403.96  274.70  427    2012  1327.38  230.99  131      Table 1 Mean hare weights, standard deviation, and observations by year.
 Citations: Kielland, Knut; Chapin, F. Stuart; Ruess, Roger W. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present, Bonanza Creek LTER - University of Alaska Fairbanks. BNZ:55, http://www.lter.uaf.edu/data/data-detail/id/55. doi:10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14
Nils Chr. Stenseth, Wilhelm Falck, Ottar N. Bjørnstad, Charles J. Krebs. Population regulation in snowshoe hare and Canadian lynx: Asymmetric food web configurations between hare and lynx. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences May 1997, 94 (10) 5147-5152; DOI: 10.1073/pnas.94.10.5147
summary:
Exploring Snowshoe Hare population in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest Snowshoe Hares are a keystone prey species in boreal forests. Snowshoe hare population density influences the ecosystem in both bottom-up and top-down ways: hare population density is linked to both vegetation abundance and predator abundance (Stenseth et al, 1997). Here, snowshoe hare weights and population density are compared through time.
Data were obtained from the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest Long Term Ecological Research Program.
title: Snowshoe Hares in Bonanza Creek

content:
Introduction Bonneville Dam, Oregon has collected 80 years of steelhead counts from its fish ladder, beginning in 1939. Steelhead are sea run rainbow trout (Oncorhynhus mykiss), and were significantly affected by dam development and river alteration in the 20th century. Here, I explore counts of the endangered species over all years for the Bonneville Dam.
Data was provided by the University of Washington DART program, and collected by the Army Corps of Engineers.
Steelhead trout. Photo: NOAA Fisheries
 Bonneville Dam,Oregon. Photo: Richard Walker
 fish <- read_csv(here("data", "cbr_fish_passage_bonneville_allyrs_steelhead.csv")) %>% clean_names() # Clean up these dates with the lubridate:: package fish_clean <- fish %>% mutate(day_month = str_c(fish$year, fish$mm_dd, sep = '-')) %>% mutate(date = lubridate::ydm(day_month)) %>% mutate(year = lubridate::year(date)) %>% mutate(month = lubridate::month(date, label = TRUE)) %>% drop_na() daily_ct <- ggplot(data = fish_clean, aes(x = date, y = value)) + geom_line() + theme_bw() + scale_x_date(expand = c(0,0)) + scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0,0), limits = c(0, 35000)) + labs(title = "Daily Steelhead count data, Bonneville Dam", x = "Year", y = "Count") ggsave("daily_ct.png", plot = daily_ct) Fig. 1 Daily counts for steelhead at the Bonneville Dam for all years.
 A plot of daily counts over the whole time frame suggests that steelhead passage is seasonal.Each year appears to have a spike where steelhead migration is high. We can explore seasonality in a season plot:
# First, make a summary data frame with total counts per date and parsed year and month fish_count <- fish_clean %>% group_by(date) %>% summarize(value = sum(value)) %>% mutate(year = year(date), month = month(date, label = TRUE)) %>% mutate(month_sep = str_c(year, month, sep = '-')) %>% mutate(y_m = tsibble::yearmonth(month_sep)) ## Let's take monthly means so it's clearer... fish_sum <- fish_count %>% group_by(year, month) %>% summarize(value = sum(value)) %>% mutate(month_sep = str_c(year, month, sep = '-')) %>% mutate(y_m = tsibble::yearmonth(month_sep)) # Then, plot it as a season plot! season_plot <- ggplot(data = fish_sum, aes(x = month, y = value, group = year)) + geom_line(aes(color = year)) + scale_color_continuous(low = "blue", high = "red") + scale_x_discrete(expand = c(0,0)) + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0,400000), expand = c(0,0)) + theme_bw() + labs(title = "Season plot for Steelhead counts", x = "Month", y = "Count", color = "Year") ggsave("season.png", plot = season_plot) Fig 2. Season plot for steelhead counts. Each line represents one year of data. Counts are total counts per month. Data from 1939-2019.
 A season plot shows that steelhead pass through the Bonneville Dam mainly during summer months. It also indicates that steelhead counts have changed through the years, and seem more abundant recently. We can explore this by plotting yearly counts:
# What about annual counts? fish_ann <- fish_count %>% group_by(year) %>% summarize(count = sum(value)) ann_ct <- ggplot(fish_ann, aes(x = year, y = count)) + geom_line() + theme_bw() + labs(title = "Changes in annual steelhead counts", x = "Year", y = "Count") + scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0,0)) ggsave("ann_ct.png", plot = ann_ct) Fig 3. Total steelhead counts per year
 This plot shows that steelhead numbers have, in general, increased through time.
